Functional Grammar of the English Language

(Tentative syllabus)

Course Description
==================

One of mankind's most distinctive and consequential cognitive capacities is our unique ability to express an infinite variety of thoughts and experiences through an almost unlimited number of meaningful linguistic expressions. Therefore, language is meaningful and grammar is motivated. Under this usage-based view of grammar, this course aims to examine English grammar from a functional perspective, and to further bridge the gap between theory and practice in study of grammar. Course content includes:

1.  critical review of traditional accounts of English grammar
2.  brief introduction to basic principles in functional grammar (e.g. prototype, iconicity, and markedness)
3.  re-examination of some grammar patterns in English (e.g. word classification, basic sentence patterns, tense & aspect, reference &definiteness, voice & de-transitivization, contrastive focus constructions, etc.)
4.  hands-on tutorials on how to use corpus-based tools for usage-based analyses of grammar

Course requirements include class participation, (take-home) assignments and a final exam. For each week, the first half of the course will be held mainly in a lecture-based format, with critical questions provided for in-class discussions and interactions. The second half of the course will include a tutorial session on how to utilize existing corpus-based tools to analyze the meanings and functions of the target grammatical structures. Throughout the semester, relevant linguistic resources, toolkits, and databases will be introduced for students to develop their digital competence in exploring the functions behind linguistic structures.

This course is open to all those who are interested in the structure of the English language and hope to better their command in the pragmatic use of the language. This course has no specific prerequisites and welcomes students from other disciplines.

Readings
========

1.  Givon, Talmy. 1993. _English Grammar (I & II)_. John Benjamins.
2.  Larsen-Freeman, Diane and Marianne Celce-Murcia. 2015. _The Grammar Book: Form, Meaning, and Use for English Language Teachers._ (Third Edition). Heinle ELT.

_NB: All the reading materials are available for all the officially-enrolled students in PDF on Moodle. Also, all the supplements discussed in class will be made available on Moodle._
